data.title: Failed to launch external program msbuild
data.body:
I followed the steps of Ankit Asthana from this video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=B0xTgyCwsAo
with a simple "Hello World" example.

However, when I ">Run Build Task", I get an error:
"Failed to launch external program msbuild /property:GenerateFullPaths=true.
spawn msbuild ENOENT"
---
Tried to add MSBuild.exe (from VS 2017) to my PATH and the problem persists.

Any suggestions?

data.title: [feature request]rename symbol should be more intelligent
data.body:
i have a variable `test_name`, when my cursor is between `_` and `n`, if i press `F2`, the rename symbol window is popped up, here i expect :
1. i think the cursor in the popup window(rename symbol window) should also be exactly in the same place in the source editor window instead of the whole variable name being selected.
2. if i press `arrow left` / `arrow right` key, the cursor should move left / right one character instead of moving to the most left / right
3. if i press `home` / `end` key, the cursor should move to the most left / right

when the whole variable name is double clicked and selected(cursor is at the very end of the word), if i press `F2`, the rename symbol window is popped up, and  the whole variable name in the popup window(rename symbol window) is selected , here i expect:
1. if i press `arrow left` key the first time, the selection goes away and the cursor should move towards left one character instead of moving to the most left

data.title: Visual Studio Code can not identify if i do not use @ with Component decorator
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.9.1 (f9d0c687ff2ea7aabd85fb9a43129117c0ecf519, 2017-02-09T00:26:45.394Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.1.7600
- @ issue in Comopnent decorator :

I was created a component for my application and unfortunately i forgot to mention @ with my Component decorator  

```
import {Component} from '@angular/core';

Component({
    selector:'comments',
    templateUrl:'./comments.component.html',
    styleUrls:['comments.component.css']
})
```

when i run my code error was something weird that i could not figure out what should be the solution after 1 hours of effort i had figure out that error was because of @ with Component decorator did not mentioned see above code. If this is Editor Problem please fix this in future update of visual studio code.

data.title: typo in chs translation
Minor errors with JavaScript syntax highlighter
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: OSX 10.12.2 Sierra

Steps to Reproduce:

```js
function merge(as, bs) {
  let res = []
  let ia = 0
  let ib = 0
  while (ia < as.length && ib < bs.length) { // coloring broken
    if (as[ia] < bs[ib]) {
      res.push(as[ia++]) // coloring broken
    } else {
      res.push(bs[ib++]) // coloring broken
    }
  }
  return res.concat(as.slice(ia)).concat(bs.slice(ib)) // coloring broken
}

function mergesort(array) {
  if (array.length < 2) {
    return array
  }
  const mid = Math.floor(array.length / 2)
  return merge(mergesort(array.slice(0, mid)), mergesort(array.slice(mid)))
}
```

data.title: Editing above a breakpoint removes the breakpoint

- Delete line 1, or insert a new line
- The breakpoint is removed

Previously, it would be moved.

data.title: Git authentication dialog does not appear on the task bar

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.1 (f9d0c687ff2ea7aabd85fb9a43129117c0ecf519)
- OS Version: Linux Mint 18.1 (Cinnamon)

**Steps to Reproduce:**

1. Through VS Code, try to push code to a repository where entering credentials are required

**Actual Behavior:**
The resulting git authentication dialog does not appear on the task bar.

As a result, it is possible to lose this window behind other windows and not easily recover or find the window again.  Additionally, if you minimize the authentication window causing it to be completely lost and making git actions in VS Code unavailable until you close the VS Code window.

**Expected Behavior:**
The resulting git authentication appears on the task bar.

data.title: Git authentication prompts for username when username is in URL

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.1 (f9d0c687ff2ea7aabd85fb9a43129117c0ecf519)
- OS Version: Linux Mint 18.1

**Steps to Reproduce:**

1. Have a remote where the url is specified in the url and have an eligible commit to push (VS Code requirement)
    ```bash
    git clone https://vossad01@github.com/Microsoft/vscode.git
    git commit  --allow-empty -am "demonstrate issue"
    ```
1. Open the affected repository in VS Code
1. Try to push the commit

**Actual Behavior:**

You are prompted for the username and password.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/965439/23002619/82cd17a6-f3b1-11e6-98d2-e00d9aaeb738.png)

**Expected Behavior:**

You are prompted only for the password.

data.title: options field in tasks.json with terminal runner does not seem to actually do anything for "env" or "cwd" parameters
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04 / KDE Neon Developer Edition (Plasma 5.9.2)

```
Version 1.9.1
Commit f9d0c687ff2ea7aabd85fb9a43129117c0ecf519
Date 2017-02-08T23:44:55.542Z
Shell 1.4.6
Renderer 53.0.2785.143
Node 6.5.0

Linux hostname 4.4.0-62-generic #83-Ubuntu SMP Wed Jan 18 14:10:15 UTC 2017 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
```

I can not seem to get the "env" or "cwd" parameters to actually apply to tasks defined in tasks.json.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. create the directory /tmp/options_bug
2. create the subdirectory /tmp/options_bug/test_dir
3. open new vscode instance with the workspace of /tmp/options_bug
4. define a tasks.json file as follows:
```
{
    // See https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=733558
    // for the documentation about the tasks.json format
    "version": "0.1.0",
    "_runner": "terminal",
    "tasks": [
        {
            "taskName": "env-test1",
            "command": "env | grep TESTING_ENV",
            "isShellCommand": true,
            "showOutput": "always",
            "options": {
                "env": {
                    "TESTING_ENV": "THIS IS A TEST"
                },
                "cwd": "test_dir/"
            }
        },
        {
            "taskName": "env-test2",
            "command": "echo Test: ${env.TESTING_ENV}",
            "isShellCommand": true,
            "showOutput": "always",
            "options": {
                "env": {
                    "TESTING_ENV": "THIS IS A TEST"
                },
                "cwd": "test_dir/"
            }
        },
        {
            "taskName": "cwd-test1",
            "command": "pwd",
            "isShellCommand": true,
            "showOutput": "always",
            "options": {
                "env": {
                    "TESTING_ENV": "THIS IS A TEST"
                },
                "cwd": "test_dir/"
            }
        },
        {
            "taskName": "cwd-test2",
            "command": "cd test_dir;pwd",
            "isShellCommand": true,
            "showOutput": "always",
            "options": {
                "env": {
                    "TESTING_ENV": "THIS IS A TEST"
                },
                "cwd": "test_dir/"
            }
        }
    ]
}
```

I expect to see the TESTING_ENV environment variable defined in the environment and accessible. That does not seem to be the case.

I expect the tasks to start in the current working directory of "test_dir", but instead they start in the workspace directory as normal. The "cwd-test2" task exists solely to prove that the directory in question is available and accessible.

Output from the tasks:

**[env-test1]**
`PTYSHELLARG1=env | grep TESTING_ENV`
`Press any key to close the terminal`

**[env-test2]**
`Test:`
`Press any key to close the terminal`

**[cwd-test1]**
`/tmp/options_bug`
`Press any key to close the terminal`

**[cwd-test2]**
`/tmp/options_bug/test_dir`
`Press any key to close the terminal`
